questions.text: Which window setting would be most appropriate for viewing bone structures in a CT scan?

choices.text: Low window level and narrow window width
High window level and wide window width
Low window level and wide window width
High window level and narrow window width

questions.solution:
High window level and wide window width are ideal for visualizing dense structures like bone because it allows for better differentiation of highly dense tissues.

 

In CT imaging, the window refers to the range of Hounsfield units (HU) that are displayed on the CT image, allowing radiologists to better visualize specific tissues or structures by adjusting the image contrast.

 

The window settings include two key components:

 

Window Width (WW):

  • This defines the range of Hounsfield units that will be displayed. It controls the contrast of the image.
  • A narrow window width is used for better contrast of soft tissues.
  • A wide window width is used for imaging high-contrast structures like bone.

 

Window Level (WL):

  • This determines the central Hounsfield value of the window range and adjusts the brightness of the image.
  • A higher window level is used to visualize dense tissues like bones.
  • A lower window level is used for soft tissues.

 

Types of CT Windows:

  • Bone window: High window level and wide window width to clearly view bones and other dense structures.
  • Lung window: Narrow window width and lower window level for optimal visualization of lung parenchyma and air spaces.
  • Soft tissue window: Lower window level and narrower width to focus on soft tissue structures like muscles, organs, and the brain.

 

Low window level and narrow window width (Option A): are more suitable for soft tissues where contrast needs to be enhanced, not for dense structures like bone.

 

Low window level and wide window width (Option C): would reduce brightness, making it harder to see dense structures like bones.


High window level and narrow window width (Option D): While a high window level is appropriate for bones, a narrow window width would reduce the ability to distinguish different densities within the bone itself.

questions.text: Which of the following imaging modalities requires the use of iodinated contrast for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes?
questions.solution:
DSA - Fluoroscopy requires iodinated contrast and can be used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. It is invasive, using intra-arterial contrast via catheter angiography.

 

CT Angiography

MRA

DSA - Fluoroscopy
Vessels

White

White

Black/white (fluoroscopy gives inverted images).

Contrast

Essential
  • It can be done without contrast. TOF sequence (time of flight)
  • It can be used in renal failure patients. (without gadolinum since gadolinium is nephrotoxic)

Essential

Type of contrast

Iodinated contrast

Gadolinium

(Option B ruled out)

Iodinated contrast

Route of contrast
  • IV
  • Non-invasive
  • IV
  • Non-invasive
  • Intra-arterial contrast (catheter angiography)
  • Invasive.

Application

Diagnostic

(Option A and D ruled out)

Diagnostic

Both diagnostic and therapeutic (Option C)

CT Angiography (Option A): Uses iodinated contrast but is non-invasive and only for diagnostic purposes.

questions.text: A 38 year old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain and menorrhagia due to multiple uterine fibroids. She is exploring non-invasive treatment options and wishes to avoid surgery. Her gynecologist suggests high-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU) as a potential treatment. What is the primary mechanism by which HIFU treats uterine fibroids?

choices.text: HIFU emits continuous low-energy ultrasound waves that dissolve fibroid tissue through vibration.
HIFU directs focused ultrasound energy to induce thermal damage and coagulation necrosis within the fibroid.
HIFU causes cavitation within blood vessels, disrupting the fibroid’s blood supply and leading to ischemia.
HIFU uses ultrasound energy to fragment fibroid tissue through mechanical shearing forces.

questions.solution:
HIFU directs focused ultrasound energy to induce thermal damage and coagulation necrosis within the fibroid.

 

Therapeutic applications of USG- High-intensity focused ultrasonography (HIFU)

Mechanism

(Option B)
  • Uses high-intensity ultrasound waves focused on a specific target area, delivering localized energy while minimizing damage to surrounding tissues.
  • Thermal Effects: Heat from ultrasound energy leads to coagulation necrosis.
  • Cavitation Effects: Formation and collapse of microbubbles generate mechanical forces for tissue destruction.

Applications
  • Bleeding Sites: Coagulates vessels to stop bleeding.
  • Uterine Fibroids: Induces necrosis in fibroid tissue, causing shrinkage.
  • Tumours: Destroys tumour cells in organs like the prostate, liver and breast while sparing healthy tissues.

Limitations
  • Gas or Bone Interference: Ultrasound waves can be scattered or reflected by gas or bone, reducing effectiveness.
  • Unintended Tissue Damage: Heating and damage can occur to normal tissue, especially near reflectors like bowel gas or bone.

Guidance Systems
  • Ultrasound Guidance: Real-time imaging for accurate targeting.
  • MRI Guidance: Monitors tissue temperature during treatment, allowing better control of thermal effects.

questions.text: A 62 year old woman with a history of hepatic metastases undergoes an ultrasound study using contrast-enhanced ultrasonography (CEUS) for liver lesion characterization. CEUS employs microbubbles that improve imaging of small vessels and capillaries. Which of the following is a primary advantage of CEUS compared to traditional contrast-enhanced CT or MRI?

choices.text: CEUS allows targeted drug delivery in specific lesions
CEUS allows real-time imaging with enhanced lesion detection
CEUS is a safe alternative for patients with renal impairment

questions.solution:
Unlike CT or MRI contrast agents, which can pose risks (e.g., nephrogenic systemic fibrosis with gadolinium), CEUS uses microbubbles that are well-tolerated and not nephrotoxic. This makes it an excellent choice for patients with renal impairment who need detailed imaging.

 

 

Contrast-Enhanced Ultrasonography (CEUS)

Basic Principle
  • Uses microbubbles (3-5 µm) as contrast agents
  • Microbubbles contain gases (air, nitrogen, perfluorocarbons) which are encapsulated in albumin or phospholipid shells

Mechanism

Microbubbles create acoustic impedance mismatch

↓

Generate nonlinear harmonic frequencies

↓

Enables visualization of small vessels/capillaries

Uses
  • Liver lesion characterization
  • Intervention guidance
  • Treatment response monitoring
  • Vascular flow assessment
  • Non-vascular uses (e.g., tubal patency)

Advantages / Limitations
  • Advantages
    • Enhanced lesion detection
    • Potential for targeted drug delivery
    • Safe alternative to CT/MRI contrast
    • Enables non-invasive pressure measurements

 

CEUS allows targeted drug delivery in specific lesions (Option A): CEUS has applications in targeted drug delivery, but its not primary advantage over traditional contrast-enhanced CT or MRI.


CEUS allows real-time imaging with enhanced lesion detection (Option B): One of the main advantages of CEUS is that it provides real-time imaging with enhanced visualization of small vessels and capillaries, aiding in liver lesion characterization. But this is not the primary advantage over traditional contrast-enhanced CT or MRI.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman presents to the emergency department with dull abdominal pain. An ultrasound of the abdomen is performed, and a cystic structure is seen in the right kidney. The ultrasound technician notes increased echogenicity behind the cystic structure. Which of the following best explains this ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
• Posterior acoustic enhancement artifact occurs when the ultrasound beam passes through a fluid-filled structure (like a cyst), causing less attenuation (energy loss) compared to surrounding tissue.
  • As a result, tissues behind the fluid appear brighter, which explains the increased echogenicity behind the cystic structure.

Black and white principles of USG

Posterior Acoustic Enhancement
  • Ultrasound artifact where tissues behind fluid appear brighter
  • Occurs because fluid causes less attenuation of ultrasound waves
  • Mechanism:

Ultrasound beam encounters fluid-filled structure

↓

Less energy lost passing through fluid vs. surrounding tissue

↓

More energy reaches tissues behind fluid

↓

Result: Increased echogenicity (brightness) posterior to fluid

 

  • Helpful For Identifying:
    • Cysts
    • Bladder
    • Ascites
    • Other fluid-filled structures
  • Can cause misinterpretation:
    • Example: Kidneys viewed through ascites may appear falsely hyperechoic

Posterior Acoustic shadowing

(Option A ruled out)


 
  • Ultrasound artifact appearing as dark area behind highly attenuating structures
  • Results from significant reduction in ultrasound intensity
  • Mechanism:

Ultrasound beam hits highly reflective/attenuating structure

↓

Most sound waves are blocked or reflected

↓

Little to no energy reaches tissues behind structure

↓

Result: Dark (hypoechoic) area appears on image

 
  • Helpful For Identifying:
    • Calcifications
    • Stones
    • Foreign bodies
    • Bone

Reverberation artifact (Option C): Reverberation occurs when ultrasound waves bounce back and forth between two strong reflectors, creating multiple lines on the image. This artifact does not relate to the increased brightness seen here.

Comet tail artifact (Option D): A form of reverberation artifact, comet tail appears as a series of closely spaced echoes behind a reflective object, not related to increased brightness behind a fluid-filled structure

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath following a traumatic injury. M-mode ultrasound is utilized to assess pneumothorax. Which specific ultrasound finding would indicate the absence of a pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Pleural sliding with a "seashore sign" indicates normal lung movement, seen on M-mode ultrasound. The presence of this pattern confirms that there is no pneumothorax.

  • "Barcode sign" or "stratosphere sign" is indicative of a pneumothorax, where the normal pleural sliding is absent, and the image resembles parallel horizontal lines (Option A and B ruled out).

M-mode Ultrasound
  • M-mode (Motion mode) uses a rapid sequence of B-mode scans to track organ movement relative to the probe.
  • It captures motion over time, providing clinicians with a dynamic view of structure movements, which is crucial for assessing processes that static 2D ultrasound cannot.

Clinical Applications
  • Pneumothorax: Detects air in the pleural space by visualizing pleural movement.
  • Left Ventricular Function: Assesses heart performance via measurements like E-point septal separation.
  • Cardiac Tamponade: Detects fluid around the heart.
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: Evaluates abnormal thickening of the heart muscle.
  • Diaphragmatic Kinetics: Reliable for measuring diaphragmatic movement, both at rest and during forced breathing.
  • Echocardiography: Measures heart function through mitral (MAPSE) and tricuspid (TAPSE) annular plane systolic excursions.
  • Volume Status: Evaluates fluid status via inferior and superior vena cava diameters.
  • Identifies issues like systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve and cardiac tamponade.

Advantages
  • High temporal resolution, offering precise timing of motion.
  • Quick and easy to perform, even for less experienced users.
  • Applicable across various clinical settings.


Absence of diaphragmatic movement (Option C): This is related to diaphragmatic paralysis or dysfunction, not pneumothorax, and is not a reliable indicator in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately distinguishes between A-scan from B-scan ultrasound in ophthalmology?

choices.text: A-scan provides a two-dimensional image, while B-scan provides a one-dimensional image.
A-scan is primarily used to measure axial length, whereas B-scan is used to visualize internal ocular structures.
B-scan displays spikes on a graph, while A-scan displays a dotted section of the eyeball.
A-scan requires the probe to be applied on the eyelids, while B-scan requires direct contact with the cornea.

questions.solution:
A-scan is primarily used to measure the axial length of the eye, which is crucial for intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation and anterior chamber depth measurements.

 

A-Scan (Time Amplitude)

B-Scan (Intensity Modulation)

Dimension

(Option A ruled out)

One-dimensional

Two-dimensional

Probe size

Smaller

Larger

Method

(Option D ruled out)

The patient's eye is numbed with anesthetic drops, and a small A-scan probe is applied to the cornea to collect measurements.

The B scan probe is softly positioned on the eyelids as the patient gazes in different directions to obtain various angles.

Purpose

(Option B)

Measures axial length

Visualizes internal structures

Display

(Option C ruled out)
  • Spikes on graph
  • Interpretation:
    • Spike distance = tissue measurement
    • Spike height = tissue density
    • High spikes: cornea, lens, sclera
    • Low spikes: vitreous structures

Dotted section of eyeball

Uses
  • IOL power calculation (biometry)
  • Anterior chamber depth measurement
  • Intraocular mass thickness assessment
  • Posterior segment evaluation with opaque media
  • Tumor assessment:
    • Intraocular
    • Orbital
  • Foreign body localization:
    • Intraocular
    • Intraorbital
  • Advantage: Easier interpretation of structure location/size

questions.text:
Match each type of ultrasound probe with its primary use.


	
		
			
			Probe
			
			
			Primary Use
			
		
		
			1)  
			a) Vascular, high-resolution imaging
		
		
			
			2) 
			
			b) Cardiac, endocavitary, neonatal brain
		
		
			
			3) 
			
			c) Abdominal, OBS/GYN
questions.solution:
Types of Ultrasound Transducers/ Probes
Linear
  • Shape: Rectangular/parallelogram image
  • Use: Vascular, high-resolution imaging

Convex
  • Shape: Sector image, curved top
  • Use: Abdominal, OBS/ GYN
Phased Array
  • Shape: Sector image, pointed top
  • Use: Cardiac (fits between ribs), endocavitary (like endovaginal), neonatal brain

Vector/ Trapezoidal
  • Shape: Trapezoidal image
  • Use: Abdominal, cardiac, Doppler
  • Features: Hybrid of linear & phased

questions.text: What is the primary reason for applying ultrasound gel during an ultrasound examination?

choices.text: To act as a lubricant for easier probe movement
To eliminate air pockets between the probe and skin
To cool down the transducer while in constant use

questions.solution:
• Primary reason for applying ultrasound gel during an ultrasound examination to eliminate air pockets between the probe and skin.
  • Although the gel can provide lubrication, its main purpose is not it. (Option B ruled out)

 

Ultrasound Gel

Purpose of Gel
  • Eliminates air pockets between probe and skin for effective sound transmission. (Option C)
  • Serves as a medium for sound and lubricant.

Preferred Gel
  • Hydrogel is preferred over Lipogel for easier cleaning.

Ingredients
  • Distilled water, carbomer, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), propylene glycol, glycerin, trolamine, and occasionally contains blue colorant.

Infection Control

Cover transducer and skin with plastic for patients with open wounds or skin issues.

↓

Apply gel on both sides of the plastic.

↓

Clean transducer after each use

 

Principle of USG: Ultrasound operates on the pulse-echo principle, utilizing piezoelectric materials found in the ultrasound probe's crystal.

 

Electrical pulse applied to piezoelectric crystal

↓

Crystal deforms and vibrates

↓

Sound beam generated

↓

Sound beam travels through tissues

↓

Sound beam encounters tissues and reflects echoes

↓

Reflected echoes reach the transducer

↓

Transducer vibrates due to incoming echoes

↓

Electrical voltage generated corresponding to echoes

questions.text: In which scenario would CECT be preferred over NCCT?

choices.text: Evaluating a fracture in a long bone
Assessing a lung nodule for malignancy

questions.solution:
CECT is preferred for evaluating lung nodules because the contrast enhances the visibility of the nodule and its characteristics, which helps in differentiating between benign and malignant lesions. It also allows for better assessment of surrounding structures and lymph nodes.

 

Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) and Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT)

Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT)

Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT)

NCCT refers to CT imaging performed without the use of intravenous contrast agents.

CECT involves the administration of an intravenous contrast agent to enhance the visibility of vascular structures and improve differentiation of tissues in the body.

Indications:

  • Bone Injuries: Fractures, especially of the spine and long bones. (Option A ruled out)
  • Kidney Stones: Evaluation of renal calculi (stones) and urinary tract obstruction. (Option C ruled out)
  • Head Trauma: Detecting hemorrhage or skull fractures. (Option D ruled out)
  • Acute Abdomen: Initial evaluation of acute abdominal pain (appendicitis, diverticulitis).

Indications:

  • Tumor Detection: Identifying and characterizing masses or tumors in various organs.
  • Pulmonary Diseases: Assessing lung pathology (pneumonia, lung nodules). (Option B)
  • Vascular Assessment: Evaluating blood vessels for stenosis, thrombosis, or aneurysms.
  • Infection: Assessing abscesses or inflammatory conditions where contrast can delineate structures.
  • Staging of Cancer: Determining the extent of malignancies by evaluating lymph nodes and distant metastases.
  • Assessment of Organ Perfusion: Evaluating blood flow in organs.

Advantages:

  • No Allergic Reactions: Eliminates the risk of allergic reactions to contrast agents.
  • No Need for Renal Function Assessment: Suitable for patients with renal impairment who cannot tolerate contrast.
  • Faster: Typically quicker to perform than CECT, as no time is needed for contrast administration.
  • Cost-effective: Generally less expensive than CECT.

Advantages:

  • Enhanced Visualization: Improves the contrast between different tissues, making it easier to identify abnormalities.
  • Better Soft Tissue Detail: Provides superior detail of soft tissue structures compared to NCCT.
  • Vascular Imaging: Excellent for visualizing blood vessels and detecting vascular pathologies.

Limitations:

  • Limited Diagnostic Capability: May not provide enough detail for soft tissue structures or vascular assessments.
  • Less Sensitivity: Lower sensitivity for detecting certain conditions, such as tumors or vascular abnormalities, compared to CECT.

Limitations:

  • Risk of Allergic Reactions: Possible allergic reactions to contrast agents, ranging from mild to severe (anaphylaxis).
  • Renal Impairment: Requires caution in patients with pre-existing kidney disease, as contrast can further compromise renal function (risk of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy).
  • Increased Radiation Exposure: Slightly higher radiation exposure compared to NCCT due to additional imaging phases.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough. He is a former smoker, having quit 10 years ago, and has no significant past medical history. On examination, he has clubbing of the fingers and fine crackles on lung auscultation. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern with reduced lung volumes and a decreased diffusion capacity.Which imaging modality is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis of this condition?

choices.text: Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) of the chest

questions.solution:
The given condition is Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis(IPF)

Clinical Features:

  • Progressive dyspnea (shortness of breath)
  • Dry cough
  • Clubbing of fingers
  • Fine crackles on auscultation
  • Restrictive lung pattern on pulmonary function tests

 

HRCT is the gold standard for diagnosing IPF, as it can reveal the characteristic patterns of fibrosis, such as reticular patterns, honeycombing, and ground-glass opacities.

 

HRCT showing IPF

High-Resolution CT (HRCT):

Definition

Specialized imaging technique that provides highly detailed cross-sectional images of the body's internal structures, primarily the lungs

Technique
  • Thin Collimation: Uses thin slices (usually 1 mm or less) to improve image resolution.
  • High Spatial Resolution: Optimized scanning protocols to enhance the detail of structures.
  • Breath-Holding: Images are often obtained during full inspiration to reduce motion artifacts.

Indications
  • Pulmonary Assessment: Primarily used to evaluate lung diseases, especially interstitial lung diseases (e.g., Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis, sarcoidosis).
  • Tumor Evaluation: Assessing lung nodules and tumors. (For Pancoast tumor MRI is preferred)
  • Infectious Diseases: Identifying lung infections (pneumonia, tuberculosis).

Key Imaging Features
  • Reticular Patterns: Suggestive of fibrosis and interstitial lung disease.
  • Ground-Glass Opacities: Indicate inflammation or partial consolidation.
  • Nodules and Masses: Detailed visualization of pulmonary nodules.

Advantages
  • High Sensitivity and Specificity: Superior ability to detect and characterize lung pathologies compared to standard CT or X-rays.
  • Detailed Assessment: Provides detailed anatomical information, aiding in accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.
  • 3D Reconstruction: Data can be processed to create 3D images for better anatomical visualization.

Limitations
  • Radiation Exposure: Increased radiation dose compared to conventional radiography.
  • Cost: Generally more expensive than standard imaging modalities.

 

Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) of the chest (Option A): It is not the preferred method for diagnosing IPF as it does not provide the high-resolution images necessary to visualize the specific interstitial patterns of fibrosis.

 

MRI of the chest (Option C): Not routinely used for the diagnosis of IPF; HRCT is preferred due to better visualization of lung parenchyma.


Ultrasound of the chest (Option D): Not a suitable modality for diagnosing interstitial lung diseases like IPF, as it cannot provide detailed images of lung parenchyma.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between axial and helical CT scanning?

choices.text: Axial CT uses contrast agents, while helical CT does not.
Axial CT scans in single slices, while helical CT scans continuously in a spiral.
Helical CT requires more radiation than axial CT.
Axial CT produces 3D images, while helical CT produces 2D images.

questions.solution:
The key difference is that axial CT acquires images one slice at a time, whereas helical CT continuously collects data in a spiral path as the patient moves through the scanner.

 

Axial and Helical CT: Axial CT (Computed Tomography) and Helical CT(also known as Spiral CT) are two different scanning techniques used in medical imaging to obtain cross-sectional images of the body.

 

 

Axial CT

Helical CT

Definition

  • Axial CT scans acquire images in discrete slices or cross-sections of the body. The scanner rotates around the patient, capturing one slice at a time.
  • Helical CT scans acquire images continuously in a spiral pattern as the patient moves through the scanner.
  • This allows for a continuous data stream and overlapping slices.

Data Acquisition

 
  • The table holding the patient moves in small increments between scans.
  • After each slice is acquired, the table stops to allow for the next slice to be taken.
  
  • The scanner rotates around the patient while the table moves through the gantry simultaneously, resulting in a spiral path of data collection.

Scan Time

 
  • Generally longer due to the stepwise approach, as the table must move and stop for each slice.
  
  • Much faster than axial CT, as the entire area can be scanned in a single breath-hold, which is beneficial for patients who may have difficulty remaining still.

Image Quality

 
  • Typically provides high-resolution images, making it ideal for detailed examinations, especially of the brain and other structures.
  
  • Provides good quality images and can be processed for 3D reconstructions, making it useful for dynamic studies and quick imaging.

Advantages

 
  • High-resolution images, ideal for detailed examinations.
  
  • Faster scans, less motion artifact, and the ability to reconstruct images in multiple planes.

Disadvantages

 
  • Longer scan times and may be less effective for dynamic imaging.
  
  • May require higher radiation doses depending on parameters and can have slightly lower image resolution compared to axial scans.

 

  • Axial CT uses contrast agents, while helical CT does not.(Option A): Both axial and helical CT can use contrast agents, depending on the clinical requirements.
  • Helical CT requires more radiation than axial CT.(Option C): Helical CT does not inherently require more radiation than axial CT; radiation exposure can depend on various factors, including scan parameters.

Axial CT produces 3D images, while helical CT produces 2D images.(Option D): Both axial and helical CT can be processed to create 3D images.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in their decreasing order of penetration power

1) Neutrons

2) Alpha (α) rays

3) Beta (β) rays

4) Gamma (γ) rays
questions.solution:
Penetration power is maximum with Neutrons (1) > Gamma (γ) rays (4) > Beta (β) rays (3) > Alpha (α) rays (2). Hence, the correct answer is 1>4>3>2 (Option B).

 

Alpha (α), Beta (β) & Gamma (γ) rays:

Alpha (α) rays:

Particles emitted by the nucleus through α decay, containing 2 protons and 2 neutrons.

Beta (β) rays:

Particles emitted by the nucleus through β decay, either electrons/positrons

Gamma (γ) rays:

Photons emitted by the nucleus.

Ionizing power: (damaging capacity of linear energy transfer - LET)

Alpha (α) > Beta (β) > X-Rays > Gamma (γ) rays

Penetration power:

Neutrons > Gamma (γ)rays >Beta (β)rays >Alpha (α)rays

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with sudden headache, confusion, and decreased consciousness following recent cranial surgery. CT image is given below. What is the black area seen in the CT?
questions.solution:
The scenario is of tension pneumocephalus - air trapped under pressure in the intracranial space, compressing the brain structures and showing the classic Mount Fuji sign in CT. The black area here is air.

 

In CT imaging, black areas usually correspond to low-density substances like air or fluid, which do not absorb much X-ray radiation.

 

Imaging principles of CT scan:

  • CT uses filtered x-ray beams and a computer to create cross-sectional images of the body.
  • CT slices reveal specific anatomy levels, with slice thickness chosen to minimise scatter radiation and superimposition using collimators.
  • CT data are divided into pixels, forming a matrix, each representing different image details.
  • Structures in CT images are depicted in varying shades of grey based on x-ray beam attenuation principles.
  • The linear attenuation coefficient quantifies photon interaction with matter and varies with density, atomic number, and energy.
  • Higher density and atomic number lead to more significant attenuation, affecting image contrast.
  • CT images reflect these coefficients, showing denser materials as white and less dense ones as black.
  • Contrast agents, like iodine, temporarily modify structure density differences for better visualization.

Imaging principles of X-Ray:

X-ray Appearance Cause Examples
Black X-rays pass through less dense tissues and reach the cassette with more energy Air or gas, e.g., lungs, bowel gas
White X-rays are mostly absorbed by very dense tissues, so little reaches the cassette Bone, metal, calcified areas
Gray X-rays pass through intermediate-density tissues Soft tissues, muscles, fat, organs

 

Dense structures like bone (Option A): Appear white or light gray because they absorb more X-rays.

Soft tissues like muscle (Option B): Appear in shades of gray, not black, because they have intermediate density.

Highly vascularized areas (Option D): Especially with contrast agents, appear brighter or in lighter shades, not black.

questions.text:
Match the following items with its corresponding Hounsfield Unit


	
		
			
			Item 
			
			
			Hounsfield Unit
			
		
		
			
			1.Metal
			
			
			a.1000
			
		
		
			
			2.Bone
			
			
			b.3000
			
		
		
			
			3.Air
			
			
			c.-1000
			
		
		
			
			4. Water
			
			
			d. 0
questions.solution:
The Hounsfield Unit (HU):

  • Relative quantitative measure of radiodensity used in CT (Computed Tomography) images to evaluate tissue density
  • Calculated based on the absorption/attenuation coefficient of the X-ray beam within different tissues

 

Item

Hounsfield Unit (HU)

Water

0 HU

Air

-1000 HU

Bone

1000 HU

Dense bones like the cochlea

2000 HU

Metals

3000 HU

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about Computed Tomography?

choices.text: Uses a rotating beam of X-ray
Uses more radiation than a plain X-ray
Slices are as if viewing from the head end of the bed

questions.solution:
CT slices are as if viewing from the foot end of the bed, not head end.

 

Computed Tomography (CT):

  • CT uses a rotating fan beam of X-rays (Option A ruled out) to pass through the patient and measure transmission at thousands of points
  • A computer calculates X-ray absorption at specific points in the patient and manipulates data for various image displays (Option C ruled out)
  • CT uses 10 to 100 times more radiation than plain X-rays (Option B ruled out)

CT slices are two-dimensional and shown as if viewing the patient from the foot of the bed i.e., the right side of the patient appears on the left of the image (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: C-arm is a mobile X-ray machine
Fluoroscopy shows continuous X-ray images in a monitor
In fluoroscopy, only movement of a body part can be visualized
Fluoroscopy can be used in catheter insertion

questions.solution:
In fluoroscopy movement of a body part or an instrument or contrast agent through the body can be seen in detail

 

Fluoroscopy:

  • An imaging technique that shows a continuous X-ray image on a monitor (Option B ruled out)
  • The movement of a body part or an instrument or contrast agent through the body can be seen in detail (Option C)
  • Used in :
    • Barium X-rays and enemas
    • Catheter insertion (Option D ruled out) and manipulation
    • Placement of devices within the body, such as stents
    • Angiograms
    • Orthopedic surgery

C-arm:

  • Mobile X-ray machine with a half-moon frame (Option A ruled out)
  • Allows mobility in all directions, enhancing flexibility in imaging

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about mammography?

choices.text: Grids are used to reduce scattered radiation
The craniocaudal view will show the breast with the axillary tail

questions.solution:
The mediolateral oblique view is the comprehensive view of the breast with the axillary tail, not the craniocaudal view

 

Mammography:

  • X-ray imaging method used to examine the breast for the early detection of cancer and other breast diseases
  • Primarily used for women over 40 (Option B ruled out) for breast cancer screening and follow-up after treatment (Women > 40 have less dense breast and more fatty tissues).
  • Guides biopsy and preoperative localization
  • Molybdenum targets are common. Other target/filter combinations - molybdenum/rhodium, rhodium/rhodium, tungsten/molybdenum, and tungsten/rhodium
  • Grids reduce scattered radiation (Option A ruled out)
  • The breast is compressed for better results (Option C ruled out)
  • Standard two-view mammography has a radiation dose of ~3 mGy
  • Standard Projections:
    • Mediolateral Oblique (MLO) View: Comprehensive view of the breast with the axillary tail (Option C)
    • Craniocaudal (CC) View: Visualises most of the medial and lateral breast tissue with superior-to-inferior compression

questions.text:
Match the following types of X-rays with its mechanism

 


	
		
			
			1. Film X-ray
			
			
			a. X-rays hit a detector which converts them into an electrical charge
			
		
		
			
			2. Computed Radiography
			
			
			b. X-rays strike a plate that absorbs the energy and stores it at a specific location
			
		
		
			
			3. Digital Radiography
			
			
			c. X-rays strike a fluorescent screen, producing light
questions.solution:
Type of X-ray System

Description

Film/Screen Combination

- X-ray beam strikes a fluorescent screen, producing light.

- The light exposes a film, which is then developed.
Computed Radiography (CR)

- X-rays strike a plate that absorbs the energy and stores it at a specific location.

- A laser scans the plate, releasing light from the location, which is then detected and stored in a computer.
Digital Radiography (DR)

- X-rays hit a detector, which converts them into light or an electrical charge immediately.

- The image is stored directly in a computer.

questions.text:
True about Compton effect in X-rays are

1) Interacts with the innermost electron

2) Interacts with the outermost electron

3) Responsible for contrast on the films

4) Produces scattered radiations on the films
questions.solution:
The scattered radiation produced when the electron beam reacts with the outermost electron is called Compton scatter (or) effect.

 

Compton effect & Photoelectric effect:

 

Compton effect

Photoelectric effect

Interaction

Outermost electron (Statement-2)

Innermost electron (Statement-1)

Process

Displaces the outer electron  and a high energy photon is emitted

Displaces the innermost electron and a low energy photon is emitted

Result

Scattered radiations on the film - obscures the image (Statement-4)

Responsible for Contrast in the film - Good (provides a good image) (Statement-4)

Relation to atomic number

Independent of atomic number

Directly proportional to atomic number

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the machine shown below

choices.text: Produced by sudden deceleration of moving electrons
Anode is primarily made up of Lead (Pb)
The majority of heat dissipation is by convection
Electron beam travels from anode to the cathode

questions.solution:
Image shown is an X-ray machine, which is produced by sudden deceleration of moving electrons.

X-ray:

Introduction
  • Discovered by W.C. Roentgen on 8 November 1895 (International Day of Radiology).

Production
  • By sudden deceleration of fast-moving electron beam (Option A)

Working principle
  • The Cathode (filament) is an electron source that produces the electron beam and the Anode is a tungsten target for the electron beam.
  • The electron beam travels from the cathode (negatively charged) to the anode (positively charged) (Option D)
  • Thermionic emission occurs at the Cathode.
  • Blocking of the electron beam is done at the Anode, where 99% of heat dissipation is by Radiation (Option C) and the remaining 1% escapes through the window onto a film called X-rays.

Components

The Cathode
  • Made up of Tungsten (atomic no.- 74) & Thorium.

The Anode
  • Made up of Tungsten & Rhenium (Option B).
  • Rotatory anodes are preferred (to avoid focal points), now stationary anodes are only used in Portable X-ray machines.

Glass envelope
  • Made up of Lead (Pb).

Focusing cup
  • Made up of Nickel.

Bremsstrahlung radiation (produced by the interaction of electron with nucleus) :

  • Electromagnetic radiation produced by the deceleration of a charged particle when deflected by another charged particle.
  • When an electron beam (negatively charged) travels towards the anode, the nucleus (positively charged) gets deflected and travels in a different direction.
  • Bremsstrahlung radiation depends upon the angle of deflection.

Characteristic radiation: Phenomenon similar to Bremsstrahlung radiation, but depends upon the atomic number of the element, produced by interaction of electron with the orbital shell.

questions.text:
Which among the following are examples of ionizing radiation?

1) X-rays

2) UV rays

3) MRI

4) SPECT

5) Doppler

6) IVP (Intravenous pyelography)
questions.solution:
Among the given options,

  • Ionizing radiation: X-rays, SPECT (single-photon emission computed tomography), IVP (Intravenous pyelography).
  • Non-ionizing radiation: MRI, USG-Doppler.

 

Ionizing and non-ionizing radiation:

Ionizing radiation

Non-ionizing radiation
  • Rays that have the ability to displace orbiting electrons from the atom thus causing biomolecular damage.
  • Some electromagnetic and mechanical waves do not dissipate energy and hence are called non-ionizing.
  • Conventional X-rays, Mammography, CT
  • Contrast X-rays: HSG, IVP, ERCP, Myelography
  • Nuclear imaging (gamma rays): PET, SPECT, Scintigraphy
  • UV rays
  • USG (including Doppler, FAST)
  • MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging), MRCP
  • Thermography

questions.text: Regarding X-rays in comparison to Gamma (γ) rays, that X-rays have all among the following except
questions.solution:
X-rays are extranuclear i.e the rays are emitted from processes outside the nucleus whereas Gamma (γ) rays are emitted from within the nucleus.

 

X-rays and Gamma (γ) rays:

 

X-rays

Gamma (γ) rays

Energy

Low

High

Frequency

Low

High

Penetration power

Low

High

Wavelength

High

Low

Origin

Extranuclear

Nucleus
